column1: Asherman syndrome is the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity.
A severe pelvic infection unrelated to surgery may also lead to Asherman syndrome.
Intrauterine adhesions can also form after infection with tuberculosis or schistosomiasis.
Uterine complications related to these infections are even less common.
The adhesions may cause amenorrhea (lack of menstrual periods), repeated miscarriages, and infertility.
Tests may include: - Hysteroscopy - Hysterosonogram - Transvaginal ultrasound examination - Blood tests to detect tuberculosis or schistosomiasis
This can most often be done with hysteroscopy, which uses small instruments and a camera placed into the uterus through the cervix.
Asherman syndrome can be cured with surgery.
In some cases, treatment of Asherman syndrome will not cure infertility.
